awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Fast and Scalable Combinatorial Algorithms for Data Analytics
awd_abstract_narration:
We are in an age when massive digital data continues to be collected at an extraordinarily rapid rate and with high and growing complexity (and concomitant uncertainty), when the data and the actors behind it are increasingly interconnected, and when architectures of computing platforms continue to rapidly change. Fast, robust and scalable algorithms that are simultaneously cognizant of all three dimensions (data, interconnection, and computing platform) are acutely needed for the purpose of analyzing massive datasets and extracting knowledge and insight from the data. This project (named FASCADA, Fast and Scalable Combinatorial Algorithms for Data Analysis) will explore the interplay between graph and matrix algorithms in order to develop methods for data analytics that perform at scale on contemporary platforms, with a primary focus on data that are expressed in terms of networks. Algorithmic research progress to be made in the project will be realized in software implementations, will be integrated with existing software tools when applicable, and will be made available to the wider community as open-source software. As part of the project's integrated education and outreach component, two new innovative courses, an undergraduate course on Data Science and a graduate course on Network Science, will be developed and taught. The educational effort will contribute to meeting the rapidly expanding need for a trained workforce in data science in the US economy and will contribute to US competitiveness in the global market. Underrepresented minority groups in computing sciences and engineering will be recruited and mentored through an existing, effective program in the Pacific Northwest (LSAMP), and undergraduate students from Heritage University will be mentored through summer internships at Washington State University.

The specific research aims of FASCADA are organized under four intertwined areas. (1) Enabling Scalable Data Analytics: devise novel "problem-partitioning" methods that are useful for solving, at scale, optimization problems underlying a large class of machine learning algorithms. (2) Network Analysis: develop fast algorithms for discovering and analyzing dense subgraphs in real-world networks arising from diverse domains. (3) High Performance Computing: develop effective paradigms for the parallelization of inherently sequential graph algorithms targeting many-core architectures.  (4) Algorithmic Differentiation (AD): advance AD as a technology by designing better graph-based algorithms for Hessian computation, and use AD in emerging applications, including quantifying uncertainty. A common thread that runs through all four of the areas is a focus on graph problems and their solution. The novelty of the proposed approach lies in the exploration of the bidirectional interaction between graph and matrix algorithms. Results from this effort will advance fundamental knowledge at the intersection of a range of areas, including data science, computational science and engineering, computational mathematics, and high performance computing. For further information, visit the project webpage http://www.eecs.wsu.edu/~assefaw/fascada.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this CAREER project was to explore the interplay between graph and matrix algorithms in order to develop methods for data science that perform at scale on contemporary platforms, with a primary focus on data that are expressed in terms of networks. The project had research aims organized under four intertwining thrusts and an integrated education and outreach component:

  • Aim I: Devise novel "problem partitioning" methods that are useful for solving optimization problems underlying a large class of machine learning algorithms at scale.
  • Aim II: Develop fast algorithms for discovering and analyzing dense subgraphs (and related structures) in real-world networks arising from diverse domains.
  • Aim III: Develop effective paradigms for the parallelization of inherently sequential algorithms targeting manycore architectures.
  • Aim IV: Advance Automatic Differentiation (AD) as a technology by designing better graph-based algorithms for efficient derivative computation and employ AD in applications.
  • Education and Outreach:  Develop and teach two innovative courses, an undergraduate/graduate course on data science and a graduate course on network science.

Research, education, and outreach outcomes from the project have resulted in new advancements in data science, AI, graph algorithms, and high-performance computing; enabled applications in various areas, including life sciences and healthcare; helped train the next generation of workforce in data science and AI; and increased participation of underrepresented minorities. Highlights of outcomes include:

  • Developed scalable distributed-memory parallel algorithms for community detection in graphs.
  • Developed a comprehensive suite of direction-optimizing label propagation algorithms for structure discovery in graphs.
  • Developed, evaluated, and documented paradigms for effective parallelization of inherently sequential graph algorithms on multi-core architectures.
  • Developed a middleware to support use of one-sided communication in MPI.
  • Developed algorithms for efficient computation of high-order line graphs of hypergraphs and applied the resulting algorithms to carry out novel analytics on systems that can be characterized by multi-way relationships.   
  • Developed a novel nearest-neighbors network model for analysis of biological sequence data. The model enabled gain new insights into genotype distribution of a pathogen affecting cattle and provided enhanced insights into the temporal and geographic distribution of mutations in SARS-CoV-2 Spike protein.
  • Developed robust machine learning algorithms for integration and analysis of data collected via sensor-equipped wearable systems and mobile devices. The algorithms were used in mobile health monitoring and activity recognition applications.
  • Developed novel data-efficient methods for reinforcement learning.
  • Analyzed card-swipe data about a university fitness center and discovered usage patterns and built models for predicting future visit volumes.
  • Built and analyzed a socio-technical network arising in the context of an election smartphone application used in the 2020 Iowa Democratic Caucuses.
  • Wrote a review article on Automatic Differentiation that introduces the principles of AD to a broad audience and gives as an overview of the state-of-the-art in AD research, including connections to machine learning.
  • Developed and taught a hybrid undergraduate/graduate course on data science and a graduate course on network science. The courses were offered every year since 2016 and were cumulatively taken by hundreds of students from a wide range of disciplines in science and engineering.
  • During the award period, four PhD students and two Masters degree students were graduated with excellent placement in industry and national labs.
  • Mentored dozens of undergraduate and graduate students in research and advised several student clubs.
  • Disseminated research results through more than 30 peer-reviewed publications in conferences and journals that enjoy wide international readership.    

Last Modified: 02/11/2023
Modified by: Assefaw H Gebremedhin
